<@U0BS2M4LC|moj> has joined the channel
someone recently asked about legacy refactoring

<https://speakerdeck.com/rallat/how-to-survive-a-legacy-code-apocalypse-on-android>

attachments.title: How to Survive a Legacy Code Apocalypse on Android
attachments.text: As a platform matures, the app's codebase is getting bigger. In these big codebases, there is legacy code all over the place. Working on that environment is highly unpleasant, without applying the right strategies to refactor this smelly code. Attend this class to first learn the design principles, patterns and how to apply them on Android and the payoff. Second, you will learn how you could apply these to legacy code. Testing will play a huge role in this. The class will be really pragmatic, and the idea is to show a pattern and how to apply it to a real piece of code. You will see principles and patterns and how to apply them on Android. Having a strong test suite is key for refactoring and improving your code and will give you the ability to make changes faster without breaking features. <http://www.andevcon.com/classes#HowtoSurviveaLegacyCodeApocalypseonAndroid>
attachments.fallback: Speaker Deck: How to Survive a Legacy Code Apocalypse on Android

and parentheses?
You can select the +32 or whatever country you're from
And validation perhaps
why not have a spinner with all the country codes in it?

or autofills the country code based on phone locale?
That too perhaps
I can make it myself if it doesn't exist yet
so my thought at least
would be to have an EditText with a textwatcher attached to it
that can add the parentheses, spaces and dashes as it gets filled
with a spinner and a selection of country codes in it next to the EditText
there is a lib I think
i’d be surprised if there wasn’t one already
not sure the name, but i know there is

different countries use different syntax
yeah, sorry, thinking in an American mindset here haha
just put parentheses around the first three, and separate the next three from the last four! done and done

Okay all, I’ve got a really weird problem
not sure if there’s a solution, but maybe you guys can help me out
I’ve got an intent filter in my app that handles a custom url schema, which looks something like this:
https://<appname>.me/<base64encodedString>

so if someone doesn’t have the app installed yet, this link can be opened in chrome and will present you with instructions to go download the app, and has a button that you are instructed to press once you’ve downloaded the app
which incidentally is the same link that you receive in your email
however, even if you chose “only once” instead of always for chrome/browser to handle that link
once your inside that session of chrome, chrome will continue to intercept those links and try and open them
when in reality I need the app to then handle it
is there any workaround for something like this?
does it still happen after a soft reset?
maybe the browser is still in memory and will last for the current session
that’s what I’m thinking
basically instead of clicking on the button int he browser
you have to go back to gmail and click the link
in your email
yup, that’s what you have to do
once your in chrome it seems like chrome takes complete control
yes
so you either kill it via manager
or it’ll still happen
Oh, <@U0A0S0WG0> this is one of those fucking retarded things
Can you put an intent on the button instead?
Like why does it need to be the same link? Just launch your app directly
I really think once the user sets it, they have to manually unset it.
A work around I have used in the past, its to do a slight forced redirect in the browser to a custom protocol
so myapp://
<https://developer.chrome.com/multidevice/android/intents>
Set the fallback url to the link
Got it. This blows. Client is trying to launch today and this completely breaks their onboarding process.
<@U0548MM6B>: Google has a lib for validating so there's that
Try twitter or twilio or someone,  I'm 100% sure it exists
<@U0548MM6B>: Fabric Digits has one
<@U0542GLTE>: can you explain the forced redirect a little to me?
<@U061HDV96> that might be it
And if it ain't,  extend it
I guess I will just have to tear it apart: <https://github.com/twitter/digits-android>
what does it do?
<@U0A0S0WG0>: So you would have to have something on the web side in order to do it.
"Digits lets people create an account or sign into your app using nothing but their phone number on iOS and Android."
But essentially, you would have the site redirect to myapp:// for 20-30 ms
It’s fast enough for the phone to grab it and not impede the user
Still don't know why the button needs to have the same http link. The intent:// URLs should work if you need a browser fallback or plain simple myapp://
oh, the fallback sounds neato
I need to check the docs

nothing that isn’t unfixable, I only have to mark some transient final fields as mutable, then fuck yourself google assert that they exist before every operation

Yeah, after I finish rewriting our entire testing framework using espresso (pretty much finished), I get to start working on android M permissions. So exciting, lol.
welp, confirmed now
it fucks up my archi
I was serializing the presenter on rotation, marking some fields as transient
because it made sense at that time

10/10 would nerdrage again
time to close shop, go home and think
<@U0B8R3VV4>: why are you serializing the presenter at all?
<@U0B8R3VV4>: can’t you retain it in an Activity/Fragment?
(I only mention Fragments because some people might not want to use the deprecated APIs for retaining in the Activity directly)
if you want to survive rotation
it has to go somewhere that outlasts the activity
my choice was the bundle
could have bean a retained fragment, somewhere DI in application
or a magic static
the choice was the bundle
just make everything static.. way easier
:troll: :train:
google would do it
and those guys know what they are doing
just see their apps
`android:orientation="portrait"` ftfy
I actually have that in, but I still architect for rotation
silly me
I have forced landscape in one app cause it only gets designed that way :smile:
<@U0B8R3VV4>: retain it in the Activity and it will outlast the Activity
that’s what it’s for
retain it how?
fields are killed on rotation and when denying permission
<@U0B8R3VV4>: <http://developer.android.com/reference/android/app/Activity.html#onRetainNonConfigurationInstance()>
This method was deprecated in API level 13.
ignore that
that’s what Fragments essentially use under the hood
so your suggestion is to leak?
…no
you put any object you want there, and it’ll outlast your Activity
it’s deprecated by mistake, since Google assumed everyone would move to Fragments and use setRetainInstance() there
:confused:
so this is what you used pre-14?
yup
this is what everyone used back when we were trying to retain AsyncTasks across configuration changes without using singletons
_back in the good old days_
lol
dodgy af
I like it
and if you look in Activity’s source, you’ll see they have a structure that contains that special object as well as all the Activity’s Fragment information
and Loaders too
and that structure gets saved by the system
coolio
and to refetch it?
getLastNonConfigurationInstance(); with a cast?
yup
if you’re using AppCompat you’ll want to use its methods for that though
onRetainCustomNonConfigurationInstance() I think
er, not AppCompat particularly, but FragmentActivity
actually you can’t use the regular method in FragmentActivity since its final anyway

getLastCustomNonConfigurationInstance()
Return the value previously returned from onRetainCustomNonConfigurationInstance().
because that’s what they use to manage fragments
/giphy facepalm
shortcircuiting it doesn’t mess with frags tho, right?
I wonder if this will work too for the stupid permissions
you can’t override the non-custom one

huh, I got confused. Ina single activity- multi frags approach, I have two presenters active at a time, no?
activity presenter + fragment presenter, that’s how i do it
so that tip up there can save my activity presenter, but what to do with my fragment presenter?
both activities and fragments have onSaveInstanceState right?
uhm
^ they weren’t talking about that but it was like lesson 1 in big nerd ranch so i assumed i was just missing something lol
<@U04TK850N>: you can retain both
either retain both via the Activity, or optionally retain the Fragment presenter with setRetainInstance(true)
saving state happens in multiple layers on Android
before you retain objects you should have an icicle layer in place via onSaveInstanceState
I always thought of setRetainInstance(true) as hack if your too lazy to deal with the chnage

>an icicle layer in place via onSaveInstanceState
a what?
doesn’t seem very hacky to me
just convenient :smile:

text: I would only save my DI object
because that's where all my presenters and activity-specific data lives
and I can refetch whatever from there
I could potentially put my state in it too
that simplifies the archi a lot, actually
<@U0BT1DU5C|keithm> has joined the channel
how do i subscribe on the ui thread in my presenter? I don't want to have RxAndroid stuff in there, right? Do I have to pass the Scheduler into the Presenter from the View (in the c'tor?)
use a handler
2010 style babeh
no, I'm kidding
you do want the RxJava on the presenter
that's exactly where you want it
oh you mean RxAndroid
well, inject it as a field or something so you can replace on test time
it has the same scheduler interface
so...yes
thanks, I didn't get my head around DI yet, so that whole "inject this here and there" thing is kinda far off for me atm :smile:
DI is not framework/library specific
I mean, passing Scheduler as arg to the constructor manually is DI too.
well you know what I mean, but I'll take note of the distinction :smile:
Inversion of Control is what's to learn
if possible, send any field you would create in the constructor as a parameter instead
and only have a field for those values that can't really be sent as a parameter in a method
okay, so like my Binder to talk to my service. I implemented that approach today :simple_smile:
still so much to do ._. But once I got some better architecture in this thing I'll probably push it to some repo so I can ask more specifically with code :simple_smile:
ive never understood the 'injection' term
in regards to a constructor anyways
you are making something exist not injecting it
It a DI concept
Guaranteeing something is there when you create it
i understand that i mean the term injection
you inject something into something else
if that thing doesn't exist yet you can't inject it
hence why its a constructor in the first place cause its being constructed
it should be dependency provisioning or something like that
cos it sounds cool

I came super late to the DI party, but for me it has to do with the first frameworks that were created where items were added at runtime via reflection or bean methods, so you never had to worry about manual injection
i.e. spring based monolith where every class gets @injected or @autowired every possible field
